2.31.text:
LOGAN URY: Thank
you all for coming.

3.81.text:
My name is Logan Ury, and I
run a behavioral economics team

8.83.text:
It is my pleasure to introduce
our very special guest Roman

18.51.text:
So as you probably know,
Roman is the host and creator

27.07.text:
With over 40 million downloads,
the "99% Invisible" podcast

30.71.text:
is one of those popular
podcasts in the world.

33.53.text:
Fast Company named him one of
the 100 most creative people

38.47.text:
He was a TED main stage
speaker this year,

41.15.text:
and his crowd funding campaigns
have raised over $1.16 million,

45.51.text:
making him the highest-funded
journalist in Kickstarter

49.50.text:
He is also a co-founder
of Radiotopia,

51.67.text:
a collective of groundbreaking
story-driven podcasts.

55.17.text:
And I'd like to add he also
has twin boys with possibly

58.19.text:
the coolest names ever, Mazlo
Rocket Mars and Carver Atomic

69.16.text:
LOGAN URY: So, Roman, thank
you so much for joining us.

71.45.text:
ROMAN MARS: Thank
you for having me.

72.21.text:
LOGAN URY: I want to start
with some basic questions

75.64.text:
So at one point you were
getting your PhD in genetics,

78.78.text: setting a gene cluster in corn.

81.26.text:
How did you wind up
creating "99% Invisible,"

85.37.text:
ROMAN MARS: Well, there's a lot
of distance between those two

91.65.text:
I loved going to school,
and when college ended,

95.39.text:
I just wanted to
go to more school.

99.67.text:
But then I realized after
I'd finished my classes

102.39.text:
and finished my
teaching that I was not

105.68.text: It just was not in me.

107.06.text:
And so one of the things
I loved was public radio.

110.72.text:
I listen to public
radio all the time.

117.17.text:
And at a certain point
when I moved out here,

120.45.text:
and I was listening to
a lot of public radio.

123.97.text: And I love the way they talked.

125.26.text: I love the way they did things.

126.39.text:
And it reminded me
of teaching, which

127.98.text:
is my favorite part of
being a graduate student.

130.69.text:
And so I've just made
it my mission in life

134.71.text:
to just rearrange everything to
become a public radio producer.

138.76.text:
Because I didn't know
what the job was,

140.57.text:
but I knew there
was someone who told

142.80.text:
Ray Suarez on Talk of the
Nation what questions to ask

147.71.text: And I was always good at that.

149.43.text:
And when I was a
graduate student,

151.31.text:
my favorite thing was leading
seminars, and reading papers,

155.09.text:
And I knew there was
someone who did that job.

157.13.text:
And so I rearranged my life
to kind of make that happen.

163.11.text:
because I'd been working
radio at that point for about

168.56.text:
And I'd been to Chicago and I
moved back when I had the boys.

173.81.text:
And there was the AIA of
San Francisco and KALW.

181.06.text:
They had this idea of putting
together a little architecture

183.74.text:
minute, a little drop-in
story about a local building.

188.15.text:
And they asked me what
I'd thought about that,

190.43.text:
and would I be interested
in doing something about it.

193.17.text:
And I'd began to plan it
and sort of sound design

195.89.text:
And I met with all these
people and I was like,

197.38.text:
I would totally love
to do this show.

198.94.text:
At the time I was working on
a show called "Snap Judgment."

202.86.text:
I was their first senior
producer, and sort

204.65.text: of getting them going in radio.

208.02.text:
And I loved "Snap
Judgment," but the style

217.11.text: I just am didactic by nature.

219.48.text:
And I wanted something that
used my teaching voice.

226.52.text:
And I hadn't hosted
in a long time,

228.06.text:
and so it was fun to
conceive of a project

232.53.text: And so that was what it was for.

234.70.text:
So at lunch we talked about
some of the worst pitches

238.36.text:
Where do you actually
get some of the best

242.02.text:
ROMAN MARS: I mean, the
best thing about the show,

244.10.text:
the best thing about
covering design,

245.68.text:
is that it's a way of covering
everything and nothing

250.57.text:
You can kind of find
inspiration anywhere.

252.95.text:
And so I take pictures
of things constantly.

257.53.text:
And so the best
things come from me

259.37.text:
trying to scratch
an itch of something

265.24.text:
And then it usually takes
some kind of second fact

267.88.text: to turn it into an actual story.

269.44.text:
So we'll find some weird
plaque or some weird thing

273.23.text:
and I'll have no idea
what that's about.

275.45.text:
And then it'll stick in my head,
and then another instance of it

279.43.text:
will come up and then all of
a sudden it becomes a thing.

281.80.text:
So the flag thing, which is
one of my weird obsessions,

290.03.text:
And that story, because I was
in Chicago, and I move there.

294.96.text:
And I was like, what the fuck
is that thing I see everywhere,

299.24.text: and do other cities have flags?

303.13.text:
And that was something
that stuck in my head

304.96.text:
for a long time, turning
that into a story.

309.23.text:
But it wasn't until I came
back to San Francisco,

311.27.text:
and realized I'd never
seen the flag there,

313.59.text:
and then why I'd
never seen the flag.

318.45.text:
LOGAN URY: For those who
haven't seen [INAUDIBLE],

319.75.text:
you should see the
San Francisco flag.

324.66.text: And then that became a story.

326.40.text:
And that was like the sixth
episode of "99% Invisible."

331.70.text:
And it's something that was
just kind of stuck in my craw

334.67.text:
for like a long time
until it had an outlet.

337.96.text:
LOGAN URY: So now we understand
where you get inspiration from.

340.70.text:
Can you walk us through the
process of making an episode,

343.48.text:
from getting an idea to
eventually publishing it?

346.35.text:
ROMAN MARS: Well,
in the old days

349.06.text:
I would have some
idea in my head.

350.88.text: I would start working on it.

352.05.text:
One of the great things about
it-- because in the beginning

354.51.text:
the shows were just
four minutes long--

359.59.text:
It barely has to have a story
to be four minutes long.

362.07.text:
You just have to
have a couple facts.

365.36.text:
Nowadays I have a team
of people, Sam Greenspan,

371.02.text:
and Katie Mingle,
and Avery Trufelman.

372.60.text:
They work for me and
we all sit in a room.

377.08.text:
And we get pitches
in from the outside

382.59.text:
And then we assign someone
to be the primary reporter,

386.75.text:
and that comes back to
me, and then we edit it.

399.36.text:
Basically, they come
up with an idea,

400.91.text:
we talk about what's interesting
to us about it, what's

406.90.text:
And then they go and
do the interviews

409.63.text: and start to put it together.

411.67.text:
And we discuss it again and
then they put together a script.

414.17.text:
And then that script goes
through all these iterations,

417.69.text:
and then we perform it
a couple times together.

420.36.text: And then we perform it to tape.

422.81.text:
LOGAN URY: So how
long will that take?

425.38.text:
ROMAN MARS: I would say on
average a comfortable show

430.71.text: takes about four to five weeks.

433.85.text:
And does most of what you
record get put into an episode?

437.55.text: ROMAN MARS: Oh no not even--

438.72.text:
LOGAN URY: What percentage
do you think makes it in?

441.69.text:
I would say every single
interview is usually an hour,

444.56.text:
and we probably use four
or five minutes of it.

447.97.text: LOGAN URY: Or none of it.

449.01.text: ROMAN MARS: Or none of it.

452.44.text:
And then we kill certain
stories we pursued.

455.67.text:
They're just not working,
and they just get killed.

457.85.text:
That's a luxury that happens
when you have a staff.

461.48.text:
Back in the old days, I
would squeeze a story.

466.87.text:
If I had pursued it at all,
it was going to go on the air.

471.16.text: Because it was my nighttime job.

472.53.text: I had to make it count.

474.90.text:
LOGAN URY: Can you
tell us about some

476.44.text:
of your favorite episodes
or favorite things

481.50.text:
ROMAN MARS: I'm terrible

I can tell you my

My least favorite

488.88.text:
And I'm just like,
God, this sucks.

490.54.text:
LOGAN URY: What about

495.76.text:
ROMAN MARS: One of
the things that's

503.57.text:
And so I like tapping into

And I catch it very
quickly or easily so

513.54.text:
if someone's really
into sidewalk stamps,

519.53.text:
And then I began taking
photographs of sidewalk stamps

524.02.text:
LOGAN URY: I think of you
as the manhole cover guy.

527.22.text:
So what I love is
when people ask

528.96.text:
me what's the quintessential
"99% Invisible" episode,

531.80.text:
I always say it's
like we cover manhole

533.96.text:
covers, even though we've

536.55.text:
And it's my internal
joke, for me and Sam.

540.76.text:
Yeah, that's our one we've never

550.43.text:
The weirdest thing that happened
in general with the show

553.49.text:
is when you start to notice
all the effort that people

562.61.text:
go into designing the world
and making it a better place.

565.80.text:
It makes you kind of
optimistic about the world,

568.36.text:
and I'm not naturally
wired that way.

571.40.text:
And I think that's
the biggest change

573.05.text: that I've seen in my life.

577.03.text:
I don't think that a lot of
the people that I grew up

581.77.text:
with when I was an angry
punk straightedge kid

588.23.text:
would say, "God, that Roman,
he just loves the world."

593.19.text:
But it kind of rewired
me a little bit.

597.09.text:
LOGAN URY: It's sort of like
a pitch for mindfulness.

599.30.text:
If you're paying attention
things around you,

601.18.text:
you're happier, because
you notice more.

605.99.text:
And that's what I've heard from
people who listen to the show.

610.33.text:
They began to tell me
the thesis of the show

614.14.text:
without me being very explicit
about the thesis of the show.

616.68.text:
About that mindfulness and
the joy of these things.

620.21.text:
LOGAN URY: Do you have a

you'd like to

I'm often asked to interview

646.70.text:
or something like that, and
I'm like, I don't want to.

ROMAN MARS: But I don't have

661.71.text:
to be interviewed on
a big stage somewhere,

663.50.text:
then I have nothing
to contribute to that.

667.36.text:
My favorite person

669.27.text:
the person who wrote some

675.13.text:
And they're just

ROMAN MARS: Like the

694.74.text:
I like connecting with

ROMAN MARS: TED

It's kind of like being here,

717.29.text: and pick shit up and drink it.

719.48.text:
You go out and grab

721.90.text:
and it's all free and
available, and everything's

734.68.text:
What I loved about
TED is I think

738.23.text: you see a lot of TED talks.

741.73.text:
I think everyone has their

744.54.text:
TED is about, and when

752.08.text:
I've done hundreds
of radio stories

754.85.text:
and I've told kinds
of stories on stage

756.62.text:
and various other formats,
but there's something

758.90.text:
about doing a TED talk
which, you're thinking, well,

763.42.text:
do I have to do it
like a TED TED talk,

765.51.text:
or do I do it like
a normal talk, or--?

770.19.text:
And so I wrote a very
TED TED talk once which

776.70.text:
was kind of the big
grand unifying theory

779.42.text: of the show and my existence.

782.76.text:
And I had little bits of
the show, the episodes,

788.14.text: and I performed it a few times.

789.95.text:
Or in live settings I
would do pieces of it

793.86.text: and see how it would fly.

795.70.text: It was terrible, and I hated it.

799.24.text:
And so I called them and
I said, "I hate my talk.

804.56.text:
I think I want to
do one on flags."

810.70.text:
I said, "I have
this one that's kind

812.20.text:
of about design in everyday
things, and the love letters

817.41.text:
that designers leave
for you in the world.

819.56.text:
And I think it's OK, but I also

825.09.text:
And they were like, "I
can tell in your voice.

827.27.text: You should do the flag one."

831.63.text:
And then I stripped
out all the clips.

835.28.text:
I was envisioning it of the
way you stand on the red dot

838.37.text:
and you have the
little microphone.

841.18.text:
And I had stripped
away all that stuff.

842.85.text:
And I said, "And
also when I perform I

846.17.text:
do this little thing
where I press the buttons

849.47.text:
and I talk over a lot
of music and stuff."

852.84.text: And they were like, "Go for it.

856.03.text: We'd love to see that happen."

858.50.text:
And so I had in my head what TED
was about, and TED is not that.

865.38.text:
If you are a neuroscientist
and you've never

867.95.text:
done a talk before, they know
how to make your talk good,

870.91.text:
and they will make
it fit that, and they

872.58.text: know how to do that talk.

874.17.text:
But if you have some idea
as to what you want to do,

877.13.text: they will totally let you go.

881.27.text:
And so I loved my
experience with them.

884.96.text:
I met weird, crazy people,
and had just a great time.

887.82.text:
LOGAN URY: What was your
favorite talk that you saw?

894.81.text:
Well, my favorite set
was a lot of my friends

900.16.text:
do a thing called "Pop Up

It was a set of-- I

907.86.text:
The most striking one

912.78.text:
Monica Lewinsky gave a

915.43.text:
It was the talk of
the whole conference.

918.28.text:
Of whether or not it was
going to be exploitative,

921.27.text:
or going to be
weird, or whatever.

922.89.text:
And she just went in and she

926.44.text: And it was a joyous thing.

930.87.text:
And my head exploded,
because in my mind, she's 24.

937.33.text:
So that was the biggest

And then the first

942.74.text:

945.57.text:
of Australia, who normalized

950.55.text:
I was like, why

957.79.text:
And that was intimidating,
but over the course,

959.81.text:
you start to see where

962.08.text:
And you're like, oh yeah,
I'm meant to be comic relief.

967.98.text:
LOGAN URY: Well, you

970.58.text: So that's the thing about TED.

971.92.text:
One of the things is there's all

The next day the Nobel

984.73.text:

But when you make them stand

not as a designer but

1048.37.text:
ROMAN MARS: Well, the one in

1053.66.text: The fax machine has to die.

Every time I get a

you're going to get that

1081.15.text:
I think our passports

Which is all that eagle

1199.66.text:
LOGAN URY: So I've heard

1201.58.text:
are more intimate than

1203.61.text: Can you talk more about that?

1206.98.text:
ROMAN MARS: Well when
I started the show, one

1209.74.text:
of things I liked
about it-- I've

1212.77.text:
sound designed a
lot of radio shows,

1215.84.text:
and there was something about
the format of the podcasting,

1219.66.text:
and the subjects and
my low-key style.

1232.54.text:
You might say, oh, you sound
different than you normally

1236.00.text:
It's like, well, I mike the
show really close to my face,

1243.36.text:
My point is I'm
trying to be-- I want

1247.82.text:
to have the voice that you hear
of yourself inside your head.

1252.64.text:
Because I'm doing
this thing where

1254.49.text:
I'm trying to be your guide
through the world, and I

1257.45.text:
think that that requires
that intimate connection.

1260.64.text:
And so I was very
conscious of that

1262.41.text: when I was creating the show.

1264.50.text:
And you put these things in
your head and I'm right there.

1273.45.text:
And I know I feel that
connection to the people

1276.29.text:
that I listen to, so
I wanted to create

1277.95.text:
that intimate space with
the people who listen to me.

1281.75.text:
I thought it was really
interesting, because I've

1283.11.text:
noticed when I watch TV
shows on my laptop in my bed,

1285.86.text:
I feel really close

1289.61.text:
And then on TV I'm like,

1291.81.text:
It's just a different experience

1295.73.text:

But sometimes when

1318.27.text:
Just because that

1320.78.text:
But recently I've
just come to accept

1326.82.text:
that's the name
it's going to be.

1332.69.text:
In fact I think it's a

1335.39.text:
And I don't know if

Even in a room, we'll

2590.82.text:
and we're all making comments

2597.32.text:
In the beginning, I
didn't use scripts.

2599.06.text: I mainly wrote on the fly.

2602.09.text:
So in the beginning
when it was just me,

2603.76.text:
I would have bullet points and
I would just play the clip,

2610.05.text:
say what I was thinking, cut
it together in Pro Tools,

2612.56.text: and then write it in Pro Tools.

2615.30.text:
In a way I could
write it in Pro Tools.

2617.21.text:
And then if it didn't
work, or the breath was

2619.60.text:
wrong or something, then
I'd re-perform the thing

2623.98.text:
And I used to call
that retroscripting.

2625.60.text:
It was a way for it to sound
extemporaneous because it was.

2630.85.text:
It was really me
reacting to the take.

2632.68.text:
But it was tighter, and
I cut it and edited it,

2635.40.text:
and I would just try it again
and again until I got it right.

2638.32.text:
And so there were no
scripts in the beginning.

2640.74.text:
But now when you have to
work with other people,

2642.74.text:
you have to write
stuff down on paper.

radio producers like
